newsitem.title: USA: Congress sends tax, budget measures to White House.
newsitem.headline: Congress sends tax, budget measures to White House.

text.p: Congress on Thursday overwhelmingly approved legislation to balance the budget and cut taxes, sending the measures to President Bill Clinton for his signature.

By a bipartisan margin of 85-15, the Senate early Thursday gave final approval to legislation designed to erase the deficit by 2002 by cutting Medicare, Medicaid and other programmes while creating a new children's health initiative.

By even more lopsided margins, both chambers then passed a companion bill cutting taxes by a net $95 billion, including a $500-per-child credit, a major reduction in the capital gains rate and new incentives for higher education.
Lawmakers were bursting with bipartisan good cheer as they praised each other for coming together to finally break Washington's long habit of deficit spending.

"On both sides of the aisle and both ends of Pennsylvania Avenue, Republicans and Democrats, House and Senate and, yes, the president are all saying, 'This is good for America,'" said Senate Republican Leader Trent Lott of Mississippi.
Lott told senators he was humming "Hail to the Chief" in honour of the deal. Clinton and House Speaker Newt Gingrich held a breakfast chat on ways to sustain good relations.
At the White House, the president hailed approval as "the achievement of a generation and a triumph for every American."
"This budget marks an end to decades of deficits and just as important, it honours our values," Clinton said.
Not everyone was happy. House Democratic Leader Dick Gephardt, a possible presidential contender, voted against the budget and tax bills.

"This budget has a deficit of fairness, a deficit of investment and a deficit of dollars," Gephardt said. He complained important social programmes were being cut to finance tax cuts that would mainly benefit the well-off.

Some conservative Republicans, including Texas Sen. Phil Gramm, opposed the spending bill arguing it avoided needed long-term reforms of Medicare while creating a new $24 billion programme for children's health.

There was also a late flareup as Democrats complained Republicans had inserted a last-minute provision in the tax bill that would deduct revenues generated by a 15-cents-per-pack increase in the cigarette tax from industry payments under a proposed settlement of state lawsuits.

Republicans have long made balancing the budget and cutting taxes a top priority. That goal appeared out of reach in 1995 when party leaders forced an unpopular government shutdown in a failed effort to get a more radical budget plan.

Without a single Republican vote Clinton in 1993 pushed legislation through Congress raising taxes and cutting spending. Democrats believe the tough fight over that budget legislation was a major reason they lost control of Congress.
Helped along by a robust economy that sliced the deficit, and let them sidestep some tough decisions, the two sides finally came together on this year's budget deal.
The spending bill by itself would not bring the budget into balance. The measure reduces mandatory programmes such as Medicare and Medicaid by about $130 billion over five years.
It directs Congress to find another $140 billion in cuts over that same period as part of annual spending bills, but does not specify where they are to come from.
Critics charged future Congresses will never muster the political will to cut veterans, education, nutrition and other social programmes, making the bill an empty promise.
